td.p: Maria G, Matt V & Adam B

p.span: The fastest F1 start reaction time? 0.04 seconds.
The average human? 0.2.
By the time you blink, they’re halfway to turning one, and you're still reading this sentence.

span.i: Love or hate this intro? Hit reply and tell us why!

p.span: attended the AiSummit in San Fran... and walked away with 11,000 meetings’ worth of insight.
Our
is…

a.span: You’re not too late, you’re just too slow

p.span: AiSummit 2025 was built with a clear purpose: cut the noise, bring in the doers, and talk about what’s actually happening with AI in the real world.
No giant expo halls, no over-polished product launches, just a few hundred people across startups, enterprise, and investment sitting down for one honest day of discussion.
One thing was obvious: AI agents aren’t just assistants anymore.
They’re being treated like real team members.
HubSpot has one that booked over 11,000 meetings in a single quarter.
Another’s resolving tickets fast enough to show up on the same dashboards as human reps. These aren’t side projects, they’re part of the workforce.
And just like any team member, they need support. New roles are popping up, agent trainers and agent managers, tasked with coaching, monitoring, and improving these systems.
If you’re scaling AI, you’ll need people behind the agents too.
But there’s still a gap. The tech’s moving fast, but most companies aren’t.
It’s not about the model, it’s about whether teams have the workflows and incentives in place to actually use it.
Plenty of advice landed around where to start: pick the boring stuff. If a task is repetitive and rule-based, that’s where AI can shine.
Support tickets, invoice processing, lead enrichment, less flashy but effective.
There’s also a mindset shift happening. AI is starting to do the job, not just help with it.
HubSpot’s CEO, Yamini Rangan, put it clearly: we’re moving from “software as a service” to “work as a service.”
Customers don’t just want tools,
Anthropic’s Matt Bell demoed how agents can now work in groups. One orchestrates, the others specialise in tasks like coding or research.
It’s not one bot doing everything; it’s AI working like a proper team.
And data is quickly becoming the biggest differentiator.
In a session moderated by Mindstream’s very own Matt Village, the panel talked about how performance now depends on the data behind the model, CRM records, historical trends, and unstructured logs.
Matt’s panel dug deep into the power of data in AI!
AI-first companies are also ditching traditional structures.
Some startups are running sales and support with just a few people and no middle management.
Others are hiring people who can build, sell, and support all at once. These aren’t typical org charts; they’re faster, leaner, and output-driven.
Pricing’s shifting, too. In a session featuring Mindstream’s Adam Biddlecombe, the conversation turned to outcome-based billing.
If an agent is doing the job, why charge per seat? Some companies are already charging per result, not per user.
And finally, speed came up again and again. Adam summed it up best: the only real moat now is how fast you can learn and ship.
Adam’s panel spoke about how SaaS will evolve with AI!
With access to models and infra becoming standard, the winners will be the ones who move first, and keep moving.
AiSummit wasn’t about theory, it was about what’s working on the ground.
For teams building with AI, the message was clear: go faster, structure smarter, and don’t wait for permission. The shift has already started.
AI can’t replace the raw, human, heartstring-pulling power that happens in your brain, but it sure can help you cruise through the slumps.
The next time a blank page plagues you, try one of Jason Keath’s 5 prompts for AI creativity:
The feedback focus group
The name brainstormer
The messy ad writer
The square peg content engine
The weird idea campaign generator
Transform creative struggles into consistent breakthroughs.

p.span: the iconic British rock band “
“ played their debut gig at London's Marquee Club, marking the beginning of their storied career.

Turn plain Excel files into smart dashboards in seconds. Excelmatic lets you use natural language to generate formulas, spot trends, build charts, and extract insight, without touching a single function. From sales breakdowns to anomaly detection, it handles everything from messy sheets to multi-tab monsters with ease. Great for teams that want fast, visual answers instead of fiddling with cells.
We don’t know where it goes either…
